figure_0005.title: Fig. 1.
figure_0005.caption: Hospitalization and mortality rates due to malignant skin neoplasms (×100,000/inhabitants) according to age group (A), gender (B) and self-reported skin color (C). Brazil, 2012‒2022. Source: SIH and SIM, adapted by the author.

figure_0010.title: Fig. 2.
figure_0010.caption: Prevalence (%) of white skin colored people in the Brazilian states. Source: SIH and SIM, adapted by the author.

figure_0015.title: Fig. 3.
figure_0015.caption: Hospitalization (A) and mortality rates (B) due to malignant skin neoplasms (×100,000/inhabitants) according to the prevalence of white skin color. Brazil, 2022. Source: SIH and SIM, adapted by the author.

figure_0020.title: Fig. 4.
figure_0020.caption: Hospitalization (A) and mortality rates (B) due to malignant skin neoplasms (×100,000/inhabitants) according to the latitude of the Brazilian capitals. Brazil, 2022. Source: SIH and SIM, adapted by the author.

claims.sentence: As shown in Fig. 1, between 2012 and 2022, it is observed that the proportions of morbidity and mortality related to malignant skin neoplasms were higher among individuals with self-reported white skin color.

Source: SIH and SIM, adapted by the author.Fig. 2 shows that the state of Santa Catarina had a higher prevalence of white skin colored individuals, reaching 83.9%, while Roraima had a lower proportion of this same population, with only 20.9%.

Source: SIH and SIM, adapted by the author.According to Fig. 3, a significant positive correlation was observed where the states with a higher prevalence of their population belonging to the self-reported white skin color also showed higher rates of morbidity and mortality from skin cancer (expressed per 100,000 inhabitants) in the year 2022.

Source: SIH and SIM, adapted by the author.As shown in Fig. 4, a significant negative correlation was observed between the capitals of the Brazilian states of more extreme latitudes with the highest morbidity and mortality rates in the year 2022.

As shown in Fig. 1, between 2012 and 2022, it is observed that the proportions of morbidity and mortality related to malignant skin neoplasms were higher among individuals with self-reported white skin color.
Fig. 2 shows that the state of Santa Catarina had a higher prevalence of white skin colored individuals, reaching 83.9%, while Roraima had a lower proportion of this same population, with only 20.9%.

According to Fig. 3, a significant positive correlation was observed where the states with a higher prevalence of their population belonging to the self-reported white skin color also showed higher rates of morbidity and mortality from skin cancer (expressed per 100,000 inhabitants) in the year 2022.

As shown in Fig. 4, a significant negative correlation was observed between the capitals of the Brazilian states of more extreme latitudes with the highest morbidity and mortality rates in the year 2022.
